central_thesis: The Scroll of Set for December 1996 serves as a multifaceted publication for members of the Temple of Set, detailing recent organizational changes (Grand Master appointments, Order developments), offering philosophical and practical guidance for personal and magical development (Xeper, Inverse Resonance, Year's End practices, Chaos Magick), discussing internal debates (Satanist terminology), and providing cultural content (music, art, poetry, online resources) relevant to the Setian ethos of self-deification and individual awakening.

structure_content.summary: Discusses the transition of Grand Mastership of the Order of Leviathan to Magister Michael Kelly, emphasizing the Order's global expansion and the opening of membership. The author, as Grand Master Emeritus, outlines future plans for continued Priesthood duties and writing.

Offers practical advice for Setians on self-assessment and magical preparation for the coming year, including rereading foundational texts, updating community records, and identifying areas for personal Mastery.

Explores 'Resonance' as a dynamic mechanism in Setian philosophy, connecting Æonic Words and the Left-Hand Path to individual transformation. It details how 'doing' generates results, how 'density' is focused through the Word to combat dispersion of the self, and how 'synchronicity' is achieved through the separation and alignment of self-aspects.

Announces the remanifestation of The Soa Gild, a volunteer mentorship program within the Temple of Set for I° Setians, focusing on foundational reading materials under the guidance of Soa Adepts and Priests.

Details plans to convert the 'Ruby Tablet of Set' into digital formats for distribution by 1997-1998 and solicits volunteers for tasks such as scanning, word processing, HTML conversion, and database indexing.

Informs members about new and existing email mailing lists for various Setian activities, including 'cybermagic' (tech discussion), 'tosweb.pub' (Temple web pages), 'tosweb' (intranet development), and Order-specific forums.

Reflects on the nature of magical tools and systems, arguing that their power comes from the magician, not the tools themselves. Emphasizes understanding underlying principles and focusing on self-development (Left-Hand Path) rather than external aids.
Announces the availability of Don Webb's book 'The Seven Faces of Darkness: Practical Typhonian Magic,' a study of Set-Typhon aimed at increasing the power of the Æon of Set.

Presents an argument against the continued use of 'Satanist' terminology for Setians, highlighting its confusing, misleading, and negative connotations derived from Christian and LaVeyan contexts, advocating for the term 'Setian' instead.
A compilation of humorous, insightful, or memorable quotes and statements made during a recent Temple of Set Conclave.

Offers a Setian perspective on Chaos Magick Theory (CMT), defining it as a meta-paradigm focused on practical results and paradigm shifting, rather than fixed dogma. It outlines core formulas and emphasizes the magician's responsibility for results through work and self-analysis.

structure_content.chapter_title: C.G. Jung on the Principle of Isolate Intelligence
structure_content.summary: Features a quote from C.G. Jung asserting that the ego and consciousness cannot be entirely eliminated, even in deep samadhi, as that would render the experience non-existent and unrememberable.
A list of 31 cynical 'words of wisdom' for navigating difficult times, emphasizing pragmatism, self-interest, and a realistic view of human nature.
Interprets the Rune Gibor as representing the 'Gift of Set,' symbolizing 'becoming one with god' and requiring hard work to accept. It links Gibor's visual form to Xeper.
A personal testimony describing the author's transformative journey through magic and Setianism, emphasizing the Temple of Set's role in her self-deification and the attainment of Xeper.

structure_content.chapter_title: Setian Philosophy, Veganism, Nature, and Unnature
structure_content.summary: Discusses veganism from a Setian perspective, defining its scope and exploring reasons for adoption. The author argues for humans as 'unnatural creatures' and posits that animals do not possess 'rights' in a human-centric sense, advocating for their exclusion rather than inclusion in human society.
Lists recent initiatory recognitions within the Temple of Set, including the elevation of Roger Whitaker to Master of the Temple and several individuals to Adept II° or Priesthood III°.

Describes two World Wide Web sites for The Occult Institute of Technology, offering advanced Setian research materials, archives, and resources for members, including essays and information on the World of the Æon and Xeper.
A poem reflecting on the quest for secret magical knowledge, self-discovery, and overcoming failures, invoking themes of inner fire, strange moons, and ancient wisdom.
An addendum to a previous article, providing resources (website and video) for those interested in the Burning Man Festival.

Explores Dark Alchemy as a process for the 'recreation of an internal structure called the self' (Xeper/individuation), drawing parallels with alchemical transformation and the Black Flame, and linking subjective and objective realities through the self.
Acknowledges and thanks the Set Amentet Pylon for their humorous choral performances at the recent Conclave, featuring Setian-themed songs.

Announces the establishment of The Order of Kronos, structured around three elements (Warrior, Science, Mystic), each with its Master. It outlines the Order's focus on Atlantean ancestral workings, personal development through a chosen magical name, and specific pursuits within each element.

structure_content.chapter_title: A Demon in my View: An Introduction to the Scholomance Pylon
structure_content.summary: Introduces the Scholomance Pylon as an initiatory tool for Setians dedicated to the isolate intellect and experimental Left-Hand Path magic. It emphasizes self-discovery, avoiding conventional symbolism, and utilizing new magical technologies for profound personal development.

A music review column featuring five diverse albums (Robert Johnson, The New York Jazz Ensemble, Anton Bruckner, The Black Dog, John Trudell), analyzed for their relevance to occult themes, dark qualities, and cultural impact within a Setian context.
Announces a project to compile a book of Setian artwork for internal Temple distribution and invites interested artists to contribute.

structure_content.chapter_title: Studies in the Origins of Runic Inscriptions
structure_content.summary: Discusses new archaeological evidence from Norway challenging traditional Rune origins, introducing the mythological figure of 'Kathoolat'—an ancient priest-king/octopus-dragon hybrid—and linking it to sea-worshipping cults and psychic dreams.

Presents a unique mapping of the first ten major arcana cards of the Tarot to the cyclical stages of Xeper, offering an interpretive framework for understanding personal transformation within Setian philosophy.

A devotional poem calling for the awakening of the self, recognizing its connection to the stars and the essence of Set as dark beauty and desire. It urges 'baneful and loathsome things' to 'Awake!' and revel in the night.

Reflections on Neheh (the eternal future filled with Xeper) and the concept of Mastery within the Temple of Set. It introduces the 'Master of the Sphinx' distinction for Masters who have completed their 'Masterpiece' and draw from a personal well of inspiration. Also includes a summary of the recent Conclave activities and the presentation of a stela to Michael A. Aquino.

key_concepts.definition: The core Setian principle of individual self-deification, 'to become,' representing a continuous process of personal transformation, individuation, and the evolution of consciousness.

A dynamic metaphysical mechanism described as maintaining and extending the energies of Æonic Words and the Left-Hand Path within culture and individuals. It manifests as paths to deeper understanding and enables Initiates to 'step into' the generalized activities of the Æon, driven by will and desire to create.
Understood as the given potential and energy within an area, which is focused and concentrated through the Word(s) of the Æon to counteract and defeat the dispersion of the self.

A primary tool for initiating density and self-creation, giving significance and focus to actions that contribute to overcoming the dispersion of the self. It acts as the procedural apparatus between divine inspiration and creation.

A magical and philosophical orientation focused on individual will, self-deification, and the separation or disintegration of the 'fused, non-separated self,' as opposed to the Right-Hand Path's emphasis on merging with an external divine.

The operative side of magic within Setianism, focused on the individual will and obtaining concrete results, often in contrast to more passive or dogma-bound magical practices. Greater Black Magic encompasses processes like Dark Alchemy for self-creation.

A meta-paradigm emphasizing the practical performance of magical acts and obtaining results, rather than adherence to fixed dogma. It involves paradigm shifting and utilizes formulas like M=GL(1-A)(1-R) to quantify magical efficacy.
A state of extreme consciousness and total mental focus, which is a key component in the Chaos Magick formula for magical impact. It can be achieved through intense excitement or deep meditation.

A new Setian distinction for Masters who have achieved 'Ultima Runa' (completed a 'Masterpiece' or vehicle for teaching) and choose to draw inspiration from a purely personal, internalized well, rather than the current 'fever' of the Temple. It signifies a unique direction of Work, not an initiatory degree.
The eternal future, specifically conceived as a state waiting to be filled with the deeds of Xeper, and governed by Set-Heh (the Eternal Set).

An ancient priest-king, depicted as an octopus/dragon hybrid, discovered through new archaeological findings related to runic inscriptions. He is associated with a primordial sea-worshipping cult, believed to have ruled from beyond the stars and currently 'sleeps and waits' to rise again, communicating through psychic dreams.

Interpreted through the Rune Gibor, this is considered the greatest gift, representing 'becoming one with god.' Accepting this gift is central to the Setian path but requires significant personal effort and 'hard work.'

An initiatory tool and academy within the Temple of Set focused on the isolate intellect and experimental Left-Hand Path magic. It aims to transcend conventional symbolism, employ new magical technologies, and foster profound self-discovery to develop the individual's highest genius (daimon).

A process of symbolic and practical work aimed at the 'recreation of an internal structure called the self' (Xeper), drawing parallels with alchemical transformations. It focuses on the self's principles in Lesser and Greater Black Magic, recognizing 'mysteries of terror' as transformative agents.

practical_system.description: The text describes a multifaceted practical system centered on individual self-deification (Xeper) through the Left-Hand Path. This system integrates formalized Setian Orders, philosophical concepts like 'Inverse Resonance' for personal transformation, and a Setian interpretation of Chaos Magick (CMT) for operative magic. It emphasizes active engagement, critical self-analysis, and continuous personal growth, encouraging members to become 'Masters' of their chosen fields and to craft a 'Masterpiece' that reflects their subjective universe.
tools: The Crystal Tablet (for study and philosophical foundation)
InterCommunication Roster (for community engagement and stating magical direction)
Email mailing lists (for discussion, resource sharing, and organizational tasks, e.g., 'cybermagic', 'tosweb.pub')
Sigils and Mantras (as used in Chaos Magick to bypass conscious awareness and activate subconscious power)
Physical links or associative objects (e.g., nails, hair, old shoes, memories) for establishing connection to magical targets in CMT
Cameras and other new technologies (as experimental magical tools in Scholomance Pylon rituals)
Runes (specifically Gibor, for symbolic interpretation and self-reflection)
Tarot Major Arcana (used as a framework to map and understand the cyclical stages of Xeper)
Magical texts and papyri (e.g., Don Webb's 'The Seven Faces of Darkness' for Typhonian Magic, 'Liber Kaos' for Chaos Magick)
Martial arts, edged weapons, herbs (for the Warrior element of the Order of Kronos)
rituals: Year-End magical acts for self-assessment and preparation for the coming year, including rereading foundational texts and planning personal Mastery.
Utilization of 'The Word' to initiate 'density' and counteract 'dispersion of the self,' making every act a form of magic.

Chaos Magick practices involving achieving 'Gnosis' (extreme mental focus), establishing 'Link' to desired targets, and managing 'Conscious Awareness' and 'Subconscious Resistance' through techniques like sigils and mantras.
Experimental LHP magic within the Scholomance Pylon, which avoids familiar symbolism and utilizes new magical technologies (e.g., cameras) to explore the unknown and foster self-discovery.
Totemic shamanism, as described in the Kathoolat mythology, involving shamans calling out to Kathoolat in dreams.
Setian Conclave activities, including ceremonial 'trodding seeds' for cybermagic, the Graal Rite, and various Order-specific workings.
Initiatory rites and personalized 'Work' within newly formed Orders like Kronos and Leviathan, involving choosing a magical name and contributing to specific 'elements' (Warrior, Science, Mystic).

relevant_quotes.text: Now let the Setian shun all recitation, for the text of another is an affront to the Self.
It's reassuring to know that my future is in safe hands. That is the reason Set and I chose Michael Kelly: that our future and yours might be safe hands.
This world is the world beyond perceived strangely.

Man as we know him is not a completed being; that nature develops him only to a certain point and then leaves him to develop further, by his own efforts [i.e. GBM] and devices [i.e. LBM], or to live and die such as he was born, or to degenerate and lose capacity for development.
Satanist: "Look, we don't chop up babies or mutilate people or force anyone to experience anything they don't choose to." Picture: "Oh Yeah? Would you believe a Satanist?"

I was there (India) some time ago, trying to convince the Hindus that it is impossible to get rid of the idea of the ego or of consciousness, even in the deepest state of samadhi I tried to explain to them that if Ramakrishna, for example, had been able to get rid of his consciousness completely in his moments of profound ecstasy, then those very moments would have been non-existent. He would never have been able to remember them or to record them, or even consider them as having any existence at all.

I am alien to this race of man, yet I walk among them unrecognized, save by a perceptive few. My appearance is human to the uninitiated observer, but I am of the Abyss, and non-human in intellect and will I now accept it, for even as I am so alone, I am at once unique and magnificent in my isolation.

Oh, hear me, O ancient one, hear me: Thou art beneath the deep seas, O great and mighty lord of mystery. Grant us your wisdom and power so that we might awaken you from your sleep in your sunken isle. O great giant of the sea, awaken! Awaken Kathoolat! Awaken now!

critical_analysis.relevance: The Scroll of Set (December 1996) provides a critical window into the ongoing evolution of the Temple of Set's philosophy and practical magic. It highlights key organizational changes, such as global expansion and new initiatory orders, while simultaneously fostering intellectual debate on core Setian concepts like Xeper, Inverse Resonance, and the problematic 'Satanist' label. The inclusion of diverse articles, from Chaos Magick formulas to discussions on animal rights and music reviews, underscores the holistic and intellectually rigorous approach to self-deification characteristic of the Temple of Set, showcasing its dynamic adaptation and internal discourse.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is existing members and Initiates of the Temple of Set, offering internal communications, philosophical guidance, practical magical exercises, and updates on organizational developments. A secondary audience includes academics and practitioners of Western Esotericism, Left-Hand Path philosophy, and modern occultism interested in the specific workings and evolving thought of a prominent magical order.
